title: Daseke Hires Away USA Truck's CFO
summary: Jason Bates joins a bigger, more complex trucking company with significant debt as coronavirus rattles the sector. Daseke Inc. hired a new finance chief from smaller rival USA Truck Inc. as the company is roiled by the threat posed by coronavirus to networks as well as by gyrations in the oil market.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended April 18
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: What Comes After the Coronavirus Storm?
summary: We'll eventually get to a safe harbor, but we'll find we're a changed country.. 'We are not all in the same boat. We are all in the same storm." That succinct summation came from the writer Damian Barr this week, on Twitter . He's right. Some are in yachts, he said, and "some have just the one oar."

title: Ruth's Chris to Repay Loan Amid Outcry Over Rescue Program
summary: Treasury Department directs public companies to return aid meant for smaller businesses hurt by coronavirus pandemic. With public scrutiny of the coronavirus rescue intensifying, the Treasury Department asked publicly traded companies to repay loans they received from a federal program intended to aid small businesses.

title: States Weigh Benchmarks to Reopen
summary: Coronavirus testing, contact tracing and places to quarantine new cases are all necessary to relax lockdowns safely. The Trump administration laid out a three-phase plan for reopening the country, and states such as Georgia, Texas and Ohio have moved to loosen restrictions. But lifting lockdowns too early will bring the coronavirus roaring back, health experts say.

title: Big Oil to the Coronavirus Rescue
summary: Look whose products are crucial for fighting off Covid-19.. Anti-carbon activists don't sleep even during a pandemic, and earlier this week New York City Council members introduced a resolution to divest from banks invested in fossil fuels. Perhaps they don't know that hand sanitizer and personal protective equipment come from hydrocarbons synthesized by their arch-villain Exxon Mobil .

title: Stopping a Lawsuit Epidemic
summary: Plaintiff lawyers are massing to loot medical providers and employers in response to the coronavirus.. Millions of Americans will lose their jobs and tens of thousands will die from Covid-19. Leave it to the plaintiff bar to make money off the misery.

title: Watch Out in the South China Sea
summary: As U.S.-China tensions increase, the chance of a miscalculation grows.. With the world preoccupied by the coronavirus pandemic, China has been looking to exert more military control in the South China Sea. This week three warships from the U.S. Seventh Fleet, joined by an Australian frigate, responded by sailing into the disputed waters in a show of force. The danger is that Chinese naval officers misread America's public mood and think they can embarrass the U.S. without escalation.

title: Lawmakers Set to Take Gloves Off in Next Coronavirus Aid Fight
summary: State and local assistance, mail-in voting, deficit concerns at center stage in contentious 'Phase Four' stimulus debate. WASHINGTON-With the passage of the latest coronavirus economic-relief bill, lawmakers are now turning to the next round. But Democrats, Republicans and the Trump administration have sharp policy differences over what should be in the package-and whether it is needed at all.

title: Keep Shoddy Chinese Medical Supplies Out
summary: An embargo is the best defense against deadly defective masks, testing kits and ventilators.. Madrid

title: 'Paycheck Protection' Is Killing Restaurants
summary: They need to rehire workers to get their loans forgiven. One problem: Unemployment is paying out more than work.. The relief package moving through Congress this week might end up better remembered for how many restaurants it puts out of business than for the money it added to save them.

title: The Coronavirus Could Imperil Putin's Presidency
summary: Russia entered the crisis with a stagnant economy, and its oil-price war with the Saudis isn't helping.. The path of the coronavirus pandemic in Russia has been similar to that of other countries: Denial gives way to fear, even despair. Covid-19 has exacerbated tensions and exposed political and economic inadequacies, testing the strength and legitimacy of institutions as well as confidence in national leadership. In this regard, the pandemic could hardly have come at a worse time for the Kremlin.

title: Coronavirus as a Sequel to 'Jaws'
summary: A deadly threat forces reluctant politicians to order a shutdown of the economy.. Inspired by current events, many people are streaming old pandemic movies like "Panic in the Streets" (1950), "Outbreak" (1995) and "Contagion" (2011). Another relevant classic is the 1975 summer blockbuster "Jaws."

title: Hershey Says Social Distancing Weighs on Sales
summary: Candy maker says pandemic's effect on consumer behavior makes earnings hard to predict. Hershey Co. said the coronavirus pandemic is changing the way people shop and eat, as the chocolatier reported lower-than-expected sales and profit for the first quarter.

title: Dying Gives Us a Chance to Confront Truth
summary: Since my wife entered hospice, we've grown closer together and deeper in our faith.. Years ago I preached a sermon on death to a relatively young congregation. As I greeted congregants after the service, many smiled the Southern smile that means, "We know our manners but don't like what you said." Yet one elderly couple stopped to talk. "We've never heard a sermon on death here," I recall the wife saying. "We needed one. We're old and we know what's coming."

title: Congress Creates a Coronavirus Mess
summary: A pandemic doesn't excuse lawmakers from performing their most basic duties.. "There is always a well-known solution to every human problem-neat, plausible, and wrong," H.L. Mencken observed. Congress has found its own neat and plausible answer to the Covid-19 pandemic: spend, spend some more. Thankfully, a few elected leaders are starting to realize it's wrong.

title: Sports-Betting Operator DraftKings Set to Go Public
summary: Diamond Eagle Acquisition set the table for public listing despite pandemic canceling events. DraftKings Inc. is set to begin public trading Friday after shareholders of a special-purpose acquisition company voted to approve its takeover of the sports-betting operator.

title: 'How to Feed a Dictator' Review: Now Serving Number One
summary: A Polish journalist tracks down and talks to the chefs of ﬁve despots who ate well despite the privations faced by their citizenry.. "It has always seemed curious to me," Ford Madox Ford once wrote, "that the four fiercest of all animals, the bull, the stallion that is more terrible than the bull, the rhinoceros that is a charging castle, and Mr. Hitler, should all be vegetarians."

title: New Junk Bond Sales Add to Growing Tally
summary: MGM Resorts and Gap are among latest companies completing offerings. A rush to raise cash in the high-yield bond market picked up momentum Thursday, with US Foods Holding Corp. , Gap Inc. and MGM Resorts International among the latest companies to complete new bond sales.

title: Congressional Investigators Say WSJ Report Raises 'Deep Concerns' About Amazon
summary: Congressional committee questions whether company misled Congress following report on use of seller data. A top congressional committee investigating technology companies has questioned whether Amazon.com Inc. misled Congress in sworn testimony following an article in The Wall Street Journal detailing the company's use of third-party seller data to develop its products.

title: Lilly to Test Drug in Coronavirus Patients Soon
summary: Potential Covid-19 treatment could be ready for emergency use this fall if trials prove it safe, effective. Drugmaker Eli Lilly & Co. said it expects to begin human testing as soon as next month for an experimental Covid-19 treatment that uses antibodies derived from the blood of people who have recovered from the viral disease.

title: States See No Immediate Sign of Financial Help
summary: Governors are pushing Congress for $500 billion in aid; Sen. McConnell says he supports states using bankruptcy protection. States across the country face an increasingly grim financial outlook due to the coronavirus pandemic shutdown-with no near-term sign the federal government will come riding to the rescue.

title: Pakistan's Doctors Fear Looser Restrictions at Mosques Will Spread Virus
summary: Prime Minister Imran Khan backs plans for mosques to host prayers during Muslim holy month and for some factories and construction sites to reopen. ISLAMABAD-Pakistan's doctors are expressing alarm at the prime minister's decision to allow mosques to hold community prayers during the month of Ramadan and for many shops and offices to reopen as early as next week.

title: Grocers Hunt for Meat as Virus Hobbles Beef and Pork Plants
summary: Surging consumer demand also tightens supplies; supermarkets brace for shortages. U.S. grocers are struggling to secure meat, looking for new suppliers and selling different cuts, as the coronavirus pandemic cuts into domestic production and raises fears of shortages.

title: Intel's Earnings Rise as It Profits From Work-at-Home Computing Demand
summary: Chip maker joins many companies in pulling its full-year guidance due to uncertainty. Chip maker Intel Corp. reported a jump in first-quarter earnings, buoyed by sales in its data-center business as the work-from-home economy spurs demand for computing power, but it joined many companies in pulling full-year guidance because of business uncertainty.

title: Who Will Be Affected by Trump's Temporary Immigration Suspension?
summary: Changes for visa applicants due to restriction imposed during coronavirus pandemic will affect thousands. President Trump signed a proclamation Wednesday suspending green cards for prospective immigrants abroad for the next 60 days, which he said was necessary to safeguard American jobs during the economic slowdown caused by the coronavirus pandemic. The suspension is narrower in scope than initially anticipated, but could still significantly lower immigration levels.

title: Borden Dairy Floats Merger With Bankrupt Milk Processor Dean Foods
summary: Dean Foods bondholders are teaming up with Borden to put forth an alternative to a pending merger with Dairy Farmers of America. Borden Dairy Co. and Dean Foods Co. bondholders want to merge the two bankrupt dairy companies, proposing an alternative to Dean's pending merger with a major U.S. dairy cooperative.

title: Law Applies to Discharges Into Groundwater, Supreme Court Rules
summary: The 6-3 majority rejects narrow view of environmental law offered by Maui County, Trump administration. WASHINGTON-In a ruling that favored environmentalists, the Supreme Court said Thursday the federal Clean Water Act applies to pollution sources like pipes and wells when their discharges are essentially equivalent to polluting directly into rivers, lakes or oceans.

title: NYC Nursing Home With Dozens of Deaths During Pandemic Says It Got Little Help
summary: Cobble Hill Health Center sought state help; 'no way for us to prevent the spread under these conditions'. At a Brooklyn nursing home where at least 50 people have died who were suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus, a top administrator says his center had to go it alone for weeks during the outbreak, with little support from the state or other authorities.

title: Australia's Speedcast International Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Satellite-communications company looks to restructure in chapter 11 as coronavirus batters its offshore energy and cruise-ship customers. Speedcast International Ltd., an Australian satellite-communications company that connects cruise ships and oil rigs to internet and phone services, filed for bankruptcy protection as the energy downturn and the coronavirus pandemic have wiped out much of its business.

title: Fox Sports On-Air Talent Agrees to 15% Pay Cut
summary: Move Follows Broader Executive Belt-Tightening Moves at Parent Fox Corp.. Much of the on-air talent at Fox Sports have agreed to take a temporary pay in solidarity with broader executive salary reductions there and at parent company Fox Corp. as it deals with the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Could Upend New York-New Jersey Infrastructure Projects
summary: Port Authority may have to significantly scale back 10-year plan, executive director says. The coronavirus pandemic is threatening billions of dollars earmarked for New York City's airports and other major infrastructure projects.

title: Construction Workers Grateful for Jobs but Fearful for Health
summary: Coronavirus breeds a patchwork of safety rules for the industry, leaving workers on edge; 'It's about necessity'. For Hugo Dominguez, a construction worker in the coastal town of Lynn, Mass., the fear is always there.

title: 'Circus of Books' Review: XXX and XOXO
summary: In a Netflix documentary, the filmmaker tells the surprising story of her parents, who wound up running one of California's most storied gay porn shops.. 'Circus of Books," a fascinating documentary newly on Netflix, chronicles the rise and fall of a family business that was a mystery to the three children in the family it sustained-as schoolkids they thought it was just a local bookstore. Which it was, among other things, with its stock of books and magazines-the New York Review of Books never sold very well, although Hustler flew off the shelves. But there also were the racks of VHS tapes, and later DVDs, as well as displays of sex accessories. In fact, Circus of Books was a purveyor of hardcore porn and a center of gay life in West Hollywood, Calif., until the internet swept it away. Every good film reveals unexpected dimensions as it goes. The revelations here concern Barry and Karen Mason, the straight, plain-spoken and otherwise conventional parents who owned the store-especially Karen, a person with an exceptional gift for living with contradiction, and for resolving it.

title: 'To the Stars' Review: Sparkling Friendship
summary: Martha Stephens's coming-of-age feature follows two girls growing up in the socially strict world of 1960s Oklahoma.. A single scene near the beginning of a movie can set your expectations soaring. That happens in "To the Stars" when Iris (Kara Hayward), an unhappy, myopic farm girl, is bullied by swaggering boys as she trudges along a two-lane dirt road on her way to high school. Suddenly a rescuer appears. It's a new girl in town, Maggie (Liana Liberato), a radiant beauty with the sort of face that prompts thoughts about life being unfair, and a throwing arm worthy of a minor-league pitcher. Flinging rocks at the boys to chase them, she also hurls some choice invective, then introduces herself to Iris: "I've got a mouth like a gutter," she says cheerfully. "I'm from the city." The rest of the story doesn't live up to this dazzling entrance, but Maggie is a vivid creation, and the sense of time and place is vivid too: rural Oklahoma in the early 1960s, when sexual norms are narrowly defined and zealously enforced.

title: A Cryptocurrency Technology Finds New Use Tackling Coronavirus
summary: Blockchain could be an efficient way to source medical equipment or validate Covid-19 immunity, experts say. Blockchain technology projects are being developed by companies such as International Business Machines Corp. and Ernst & Young LLC to help with various aspects of the pandemic caused by the novel coronavirus.

title: 'School Girls; Or, the African Mean Girls Play' Review: Queen Bee Gets Stung
summary: Drama erupts inside a Ghanaian boarding school when a new student threatens to usurp the reign of a popular student.. One reason why I cover regional theater is to see promising shows that I couldn't shoehorn into my New York schedule. Jocelyn Bioh's "School Girls; Or, the African Mean Girls Play" has been at the top of that list since it opened off Broadway in 2017. An African variation on the "Mean Girls"/"Heathers" movie genre, it struck me at the time as a fabulous premise for satirical playmaking, and I've been waiting ever since to catch a regional staging. Indeed, Berkeley Repertory Theatre's production was one of the first shows closed by the coronavirus outbreak to resurface as a theatrical webcast, and I'd have reviewed it had I heard about it soon enough.

title: Fed to Disclose Loan Amounts, Borrowers on Business Lending Programs
summary: Central bank will provide monthly reports on programs to support corporate credit markets and Main Street lending. The Federal Reserve said Thursday it plans to disclose monthly the borrowers, loan amounts and interest rates on funding from several new lending programs the central bank is in the process of establishing.

title: Coronavirus Helps to Reanimate Federalism
summary: I think the President Trump's assertion of "total" authority over the states likely reflects his irritation at governors who have for weeks complained about the "lack of leadership" coming from Washington and the need for a uniform nationwide policy.. William Galston's "Trump Flunks Federalism 101" (Politics & Ideas, April 15) is excellent as far as it goes. He notes that Supreme Court decisions construing the Constitution's Spending Clause permit the federal government to offer states grants for purposes that are the exclusive responsibility of the states, so long as it doesn't coerce them into accepting them and all their attendant baggage. Experience has demonstrated that the states find it enormously difficult to decline them, whatever their conditions. That is true even though 14 states refused to participate in ObamaCare's expansion of Medicaid coverage, but that is an exception that proves the rule. Having experienced the very substantial collateral costs of their existing Medicaid programs, those states declined to compound them. Thus the practical effect of the court's Spending Clause decision has been to empower Congress to induce the states into adopting Washington's approach to matters that remain the states' exclusive responsibility.

title: Med School, Social Awareness and Good Care
summary: The most productive day of my medical education was the one I spent with a visiting nurse as she made rounds in poor areas of the South Bronx.. In "Med School Needs an Overhaul" (op-ed, April 14), Dr. Stanley Goldfarb bemoans the present focus in the curriculum for educating future doctors. Fifty years ago, when I was a medical student, we were exposed to public-health issues, epidemiology, biostatistics and community health. The most productive day of my medical education was the one I spent with a visiting nurse as she made rounds in poor areas of the South Bronx. It taught me that all of the advances in the science of medicine will be of no avail if our patients don't follow our recommended treatments. If doctors understand how our patients live, we can improve their medical outcomes. In my four years of medical school, the hours we medical students devoted to our studies far exceeded the demands on the time of friends who were studying for M.B.A.s or other graduate degrees. Given that time is finite, if we add an item to the curriculum, something else will have to be reduced.

title: Should Gender, Race Rules Apply to the Vice President?
summary: Why is it that political jobs can be filled by sex or race while jobs in the private sector cannot?. Regarding the letters of April 21 about Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden saying he would choose a woman for vice president. Why is it that political jobs can be filled by sex or race while jobs in the private sector cannot? Isn't it time to apply the same rules to the politicians who make the laws as those followed by the people who live under them?

title: 'Bad Education' Review: A Scandal With Smarts
summary: The real-life story of malfeasance inside a suburban New York school system brings a human perspective to financial crime.. The rise and fall of Frank Tassone as told in HBO's blackly comedic "Bad Education" is mostly about his fall and hinges, ever so Greekly, on his own hubris. Early on, Frank, the wildly popular, handsome and successful superintendent of the Roslyn, N.Y., school system on Long Island, is interviewed about an overly ambitious building project by a student journalist, who gets her quote and prepares to go. "It's just a puff piece," explains Rachel Bhargava (Geraldine Viswanathan), but Frank stops her in her tracks. "It's only a puff piece if you let it be a puff piece," he admonishes. "A real journalist can turn any assignment into a story." What you feel then is just a tremor, but the foundation of Frank's meticulously fabricated life is beginning to turn to sand.

title: 'Never Have I Ever' Review: Everyone's a Sidekick
summary: The new sitcom from Mindy Kaling is a quirky, rewarding high-school series.. Comedy is never safe; the best comedy is totally unsafe; and "Never Have I Ever" is the teen-sitcom equivalent of running with scissors, used hypodermic needles and a fully operating chain saw. It may also be the meta high-school series of our time.

title: Stocks Give Up Gains in Another Wild Session
summary: Gilead drug to treat Covid 19 faces potential setback, worrying investors as oil extends gains. U.S. stocks swung sharply Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average giving up most of a 400-point rally on reports that a potential treatment for Covid-19 disappointed in a clinical trial.

title: Supermarket Surge Can Outlast the Virus
summary: History indicates that supermarket sales may stay elevated in the coming economic downturn. Large grocers have done very well during the coronavirus pandemic amid newfound enthusiasm for making bread and collecting toilet paper. The benefit is likely to be more than temporary.

title: Growth Stocks Shine in Rising and Falling Markets
summary: Growth investing hasn't cooled even as big price swings have rattled U.S. stock markets. Investing in companies promising high growth in the future has become a profitable way to play rising and falling markets alike.

title: Citrix Keeps Home Field Advantage
summary: Even after a run-up, its stock is modestly valued relative to other work-from-home stars. Citrix Systems has much in common with Netflix at the moment, beyond just similar-sounding names. They share a common advantage in a global pandemic-and a common problem as well.

title: Google to Require All Advertisers to Identify Themselves
summary: New requirement will help Alphabet unit crack down on digital ads purveying fake products and coronavirus misinformation. Google said it would require all advertisers to verify their identities to purchase ads through the company's ad-buying software, a move that would help it crack down on ads purveying misinformation or products related to the coronavirus.

title: Millions of U.S. Workers Filed for Jobless Benefits Last Week
summary: Workers have filed more than 26 million claims since start of coronavirus shutdowns, but pace of new applications tapered in most states last week. About 4.4 million Americans sought unemployment benefits last week as the coronavirus pandemic continued to hurt the labor market, though the rapid pace of layoffs appeared to be easing.

title: Europe Seeks to Bridge Divisions as It Debates Recovery Fund
summary: EU leaders plan to sign off on €500 billion package intended to boost health spending, reduce unemployment and support small businesses. European leaders began debating Thursday a crisis-recovery fund that will likely total at least a trillion euros, as borrowing costs rise for Italy and Spain as a result of fears that Germany and the bloc's other wealthy countries won't sufficiently help harder-hit states avoid a surge in debt levels.

title: Supreme Court Expands Conditions for Deporting Lawful Immigrants With Criminal Records
summary: Government wins case seeking to deport a permanent resident who has lived in U.S. since childhood. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court widened the grounds for deporting lawful immigrants with criminal records in a Thursday ruling.

title: U.S. Offers Aid to Greenland to Counter China, Russia
summary: Trump administration, competing for Arctic influence, is providing $12.1 million to strategically well-placed territory. WASHINGTON-The U.S. is providing Greenland with a package of development aid as part of a strategy to counter Russian and Chinese influence in the Arctic, focusing on energy, education and tourism, officials said Thursday.

title: Oil Prices Climb as Traders Prepare for Wild Ride to Continue
summary: U.S. oil gauge recovers 20% with wild moves continuing to unsettle traders. Crude-oil prices jumped Thursday, extending a string of wild moves that are ricocheting across financial markets and roiling the global energy industry.

title: Puzzles for Adults-From Funny to Freakishly Challenging
summary: Already solved all your 'covered bridge' puzzles during quarantine? These 5 extraordinary jigsaws rise to the level of art.

title: MGM Quarterly Revenue Falls 29% on Coronavirus-Driven Closures
summary: The company said it is freezing hiring as well as laying off and furloughing employees in an effort to cut costs.. MGM Resorts International said its revenue fell 29% for the first three months of the year as the Covid-19 pandemic led to casino closures amid the global health crisis.

title: Unemployment Claims Keep Flooding Tri-State Area
summary: Nearly 450,000 initial filings reported in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut. The number of people receiving unemployment benefits in the tri-state region continues to climb as workers remain sidelined by the coronavirus pandemic, with nearly 450,000 filing initial claims in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut last week.

title: For One New York Theater, the Show Must Go Online During Coronavirus Shutdown
summary: After the pandemic shut down New York City theaters, Roundabout decided to stream its new production of '72 Miles to Go'. Days after the Roundabout Theatre Company opened its off-Broadway production of "72 Miles to Go" in March, the nonprofit troupe learned it would have to shut it down because of state-mandated pandemic restrictions.

title: Comfort Food, Springtime Edition
summary: It's ramps season, and charring them, chopping them and mixing them into a cozy potato mash is a very good idea. With lamb sausages and a garlicky mint sauce, this recipe is built to please.. BRISK SPRING days call for a cozy dish like this, the first Slow Food Fast recipe from Will Mester, chef-owner of Le Comptoir du Vin in Baltimore. Seared lamb sausages accompany a flavorful mash of potatoes, charred ramps, Parmesan, olive oil and a little mayo. (At his house, Mr. Mester likes to add an egg yolk too.) A drizzle of emerald-green mint sauce brightens the plate.

title: Coronavirus: Los hechos
summary: Lo que necesita saber sobre la enfermedad del COVID-19.. A medida que la pandemia del coronavirus cambia el trabajo, los viajes y la vida del hogar, las reglas de lo que la gente puede y no puede hacer en su vida diaria están cambiando. El Wall Street Journal está ofreciendo información en español sobre el virus, sus síntomas y cómo protegerte. Científicos y autoridades de salud pública están aprendiendo cada día más acerca del nuevo coronavirus según la pandemia avanza. Por favor, comparte esta información sobre lo que es el virus y cómo protegerte con tus amigos y tu familia.

title: How VR Home Workouts Can Make Time Fly By
summary: If Peloton and Instagram Live exercise classes have you staring at the clock, Supernatural's VR platform can help you burn fat in (seemingly) less time. WATER SPLASHES your toes and, looking down, it seems you might have accidentally kicked the edges of the jade-colored lagoon. Your eyes trick you into thinking you're getting a waterside workout in Papua New Guinea, but you're actually twirling on a yoga mat in your living room, an Oculus Quest headset strapped to your face. That water was just your own sweat raining down.

title: Confusion Hampers Coronavirus-Driven Inmate Releases
summary: Shifting policy led to some federal prisoners being told they were eligible for home confinement, only to have it revoked. The Justice Department said Wednesday that federal prison officials could consider inmates for early release even if they haven't yet served half of their sentences, clarifying a shifting policy that has sown confusion across the nation's prisons and courts in recent days.

title: Railroads Prepare for Quick Turnaround
summary: Idled by coronavirus, CSX and Union Pacific have kept workers on standby rather than let them go. After having a front-row seat to the economy seizing up, freight railroads are keeping their workers and locomotives on standby to quickly help get things moving again.

title: Public Colleges Lose State Funding, Effective Immediately
summary: Coronavirus prompts states to cut budgets of their universities; Montclair State University loses about 25% of its annual appropriation. Some public colleges and universities are starting to see their budgets cut with surprising speed, as states reckon with the economic fallout of the pandemic.

title: More Cooking, Less Shampooing: The Coronavirus Consumer Emerges
summary: Unilever, P&G, other consumer-goods giants report major shifts in shopper behavior amid lockdowns. Consumers are cooking and cleaning more while spending less time and money on grooming and makeup, consumer-products companies say, as a picture emerges of how the coronavirus is reshaping lifestyles.

title: The Other Jobs Threat: New Business Drought
summary: Data show the number of applications to start businesses has collapsed. That could equate to even more job losses.. The number of people losing their jobs and the number of businesses lowering their gates as a result of the new coronavirus crisis is beyond stunning. Less visible are many of the things that aren't getting off the ground-the new corner cafes and dentists offices, and the businesses that start small and grow into household names. These missing startups could cast a pall over the economy long after the threat from the pandemic recedes.

title: Homegrown in Minnesota
summary: This $225,000 conservatory in Minnetonka has automated lighting and watering systems, as well as vertical planters and a living wall. When a Minnetonka, Minn., couple wanted to garden all year long, they considered adding a conservatory to their home. They reached out to Conservatory Craftsmen, a Minneapolis-based building firm. "She's very ambitious, grows a lot of plants, but she grows them in pots on her deck. They're vegetarians and like eggplant and okra and spinach and kale. Her husband encouraged her to get involved with something that could grow edible plants throughout the year," says company owner Jim Hewitt.

title: Global Economy Hit by Record Collapse of Business Activity
summary: Surveys suggest governments have effectively closed parts of the economy where face-to-face interaction is unavoidable. Business activity in the U.S., Europe and Japan collapsed in April as governments tightened restrictions on movement and social interaction aimed at limiting the spread of the coronavirus, according to surveys of purchasing managers.

title: As Golf Communities Lose Popularity, Real-Estate Developers Change Course
summary: Resume Subscription. Jim and Wanda Dill had lived in a golf-course community in Naples, Fla., for 14 years when they decided to move nearby to a different master-planned community, where the main draw is water.

title: Coronavirus Erodes Confidence About Retirement Finances
summary: March survey shows workers and retirees less confident compared with high levels last year. With unemployment rising, stocks slumping and the coronavirus pandemic weighing heavily on the economy, retirees' and workers' confidence in having enough money for retirement has declined from near-record highs last year, according to a long-running survey released Thursday.

title: Canada's Dominion Diamond Files for Protection From Creditors
summary: Dominion Diamond Mines filed for bankruptcy in Canada after the coronavirus pandemic froze its operations. Dominion Diamond Mines ULC has sought bankruptcy protection from creditors after shutting down mining operations to maintain social-distancing protocols during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Juul, Rival E-Cigarette Makers Get More Time Before FDA Review Due to Coronavirus
summary: The deadline is moved from May 12 to Sept. 9 to submit e-cigarette products for federal review or take them off the market. Juul Labs Inc. and other e-cigarette makers now have until early September to either submit their vaping products for federal review or take them off the U.S. market.

title: Get Ready for the Return of Inflation
summary: Fed actions have increased the quantity of money in the U.S. economy at a blistering rate.. The economists Milton Friedman and Anna Jacobson Schwartz demonstrated in "A Monetary History of the United States" that a collapse in the quantity of money was the main cause of the Great Depression. Hoping to avoid a repeat, the Federal Reserve in recent weeks has poured money into the economy at the fastest rate in the past 200 years. Unfortunately, this overreaction could turn out just as poorly; history suggests the U.S. will soon see an inflation boom.

title: Maybe the Experts Were Right About Covid-19 the First Time
summary: They originally wanted herd immunity, realizing lockdowns would incur the disasters we're seeing.. It's time to confront an awful possibility about the lockdowns in which many of the world's economies now find themselves: The experts might have been right the first time.

title: California Pizza Kitchen Seeks Restructuring Deal
summary: Coronavirus closures have slashed sales at casual-dining chains. California Pizza Kitchen Inc. is seeking to restructure its debt to avoid a possible bankruptcy filing, according to people familiar with the discussions, as the coronavirus pandemic decimates sales at casual-dining chains.

title: More Small-Business Aid Is Coming, But It Might Not Be Enough
summary: Lenders report a backlog of loan applications for Paycheck Protection Program, which exhausted the $350 billion originally allocated for it. WASHINGTON-The House is expected to approve an additional $320 billion for the Paycheck Protection Program on Thursday, amid concerns by lenders and small-business advocates that the funding still won't be enough to meet demand for the coronavirus aid.

title: Chinese Propaganda and the Panic
summary: A sinister plot to suggest Trump might agree with the New York Times?. China's communist regime must account for its suppression of information about the novel coronavirus, which has cost thousands of lives around the world. Now the New York Times is reporting that the communist regime also directed a campaign of fake news to scare Americans about the U.S. government's plans to respond to the virus.

title: Domino's Sees Higher Sales in April
summary: The pizza chain said U.S. same-store sales jumped as consumers stayed home due to the coronavirus pandemic. Domino's Pizza Inc. said its U.S. sales accelerated in April as consumers stay at home because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Yoga's Long Journey From Magic to 'Wellness'
summary: In ancient India, practitioners were more interested in escaping the body than perfecting it.. In the last few decades, yoga has grown from an esoteric meditation practice into a global wellness industry worth $25 billion. In the U.S. alone, the number of people doing yoga shot from 4 million in 2001 to more than 37 million by 2016. But while today's yoga has become a highly respectable pastime-synonymous with physical fitness, good health and clean living-its historical roots in ancient and medieval India were decidedly less anodyne.

title: Blackstone Battered by Selloff; Gray Sees 'Elongated Recovery'
summary: Firm's assets fall as value of energy holdings tumble, though e-commerce warehouses help real-estate business. Blackstone Group Inc.'s first-quarter results were hit hard by the coronavirus-led market selloff, and the firm's president, Jonathan Gray, said he sees the economic recovery taking some time to gain steam.

title: Expedia Names New CEO, Confirms Investment From Private-Equity Firms
summary: Online-travel company will take an investment of $1.2 billion from Apollo Global Management and Silver Lake. Expedia Group Inc. named a new chief executive as the online travel-booking company confirmed it will raise billions to shore up a business that has been devastated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: As Coronavirus Weighs on Trade, South Korea Launches World's Largest Container Ship
summary: The rollout comes as Seoul is pumping $33 billion to shield key industries like transportation from the coronavirus shock. South Korea launched the world's biggest container ship Thursday at a time when carriers are drastically cutting capacity to deal with a collapse in global trade caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: In a Global First, Syrians Face Trial for State Torture
summary: Trial of two former members of the Syrian government's intelligence service begins in Germany. The first trial on Syrian state torture began Thursday in Germany, in what lawyers and human-rights groups see as a test case for the role European courts can play in accountability for war crimes committed in the Syrian conflict.

title: How Empty Hotels Are Still Offering Deluxe Service During Coronavirus
summary: Most hotels and safari lodges aren't taking guests right now, but if you're seeking online expertise, on everything from zebra factoids to cocktail tutorials, hospitality pros are sharing their know-how. WITH THE WHOLE world temporarily closed, the web is an ever more powerful resource: from how-to-make-your-own-mask videos to virtual raves. But who'd think of going to hotels-most closed for the duration-for anything besides post-apocalypse room rates or distracting photos of poolside Negronis at sunset? The truth is: Hotels harbor masses of expert information and, as we burrow into hibernation, some top names in hospitality are extending it online, free of charge.

title: Coronavirus Threatens Southern Europe's Vital Tourism Industry
summary: Hotels, restaurants and other businesses struggle to survive; 'This year will be a catastrophe'. Located on the cusp of Valencia's biggest beach and its marina, Hotel Neptuno would normally be bustling in late April as Spain's tourism season fires up. This year, the hotel is just trying to survive.

title: Barney Ales Helped Bring Motown Sound to White Audiences
summary: Executive persuaded DJs that the Supremes and Temptations had universal appeal. Motown Record Corp., founded in 1959 by Berry Gordy Jr., was a triumph of African-American entrepreneurship. One of Mr. Gordy's most important executives, however, was Barney Ales, a white guy with a goatee and no claim to musical talent.

title: My Lifelong Crusade Against the Useless Paper Towel
summary: Hoard them? No way. You're better off with a rubber sponge or old sock.. Paper towels have been flying off the shelves lately, which makes no sense whatsoever because paper towels are the most overrated household cleaning item in the history of American tidiness. Unlike soap or dishwasher detergent or the sine qua non spaghetti mop, there is almost nothing a paper towel does that can't be done equally effectively with a chamois cloth, a strip of cotton, a rubber sponge or an old sock. Yet year in, year out Americans squander a Croesian fortune on these extraneous objects.

title: China's Medical-Goods Market Is 'Wild West'
summary: Supply chain is in chaos as foreign governments, hospitals and businesses compete for the same gear. Urgent late night inspections at Chinese mask factories. Hurried million-dollar wire transfers to secure ventilator deals. Middlemen lurking outside a Shanghai factory offering masks of unknown provenance.

title: Developers Transform Former Country-Club Communities
summary: From California to South Carolina, builders lure buyers with promises of less informal, more outdoors-oriented lifestyles. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: CEOs Struggle to Master the Mute Button
summary: Virtual results season comes with a rash of audio snafus. There is a vital question being asked during the first company earnings season covering the time of the Covid-19 pandemic: "Can you hear me?"

title: Pandemic Builds Momentum for Broadband Upgrade
summary: Coronavirus crisis shows need for widespread high-speed internet in U.S. homes. WASHINGTON-The coronavirus pandemic is boosting momentum for major broadband legislation, highlighting the widespread lack of high-speed internet in U.S. homes at a time when it has become more essential than ever.

title: Zoom Fatigue Is Real
summary: Resume Subscription. When governments told citizens to adopt a hermit lifestyle in March, Jess Cripps made a lockdown bucket list. "Finally, I can sit down and learn to crochet," the 30-year-old library assistant from North Wales recalls thinking. And she planned to pickle onions.

title: At Least Six Dead as Severe Weather Hits South
summary: More than 100,000 customers from Texas to Mississippi were without power. MADILL, Okla.-Severe weather was moving through the South on Thursday after at least six people died in Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana, including a factory worker whose body was found a quarter-mile away after an apparent tornado struck his workplace and severely damaged the town nearby.

title: The Emotional Benefits of Getting Older
summary: New research shows that older people enjoy greater emotional steadiness and self-control.. There is no doubt that the coronavirus confinement has filled us with dread. It is also rife with temptation. The constant thrum of competing urges punctuates our days: We can work or we can scroll through our social media feeds and email. We can snack, drink coffee, eat, nap, take the dog for a walk and then work some more. Lather, rinse, repeat. With so much unstructured time on our hands, how do we control our urges, and who is likely to be best at the task?

title: Asia's Oil-Consuming Nations Add to Stockpiles Thanks to Bargain Prices
summary: China, India, South Korea and Australia collectively have hundreds of millions of barrels of spare capacity; their demand could help stabilize the market. Like shoppers encountering a bargain on toilet paper at a warehouse store, Asia's oil consumers are beginning to stock up on oil at rock-bottom prices for their national reserves. Their only problem is finding more closet space.

title: Joe Burrow Goes No. 1 to the Bengals in the NFL Draft
summary: The best way to understand the hype around the No. 1 pick is by looking at his flaws. There aren't many.. There wasn't a technical glitch or unforeseen stunner that threw the start of this year's NFL draft into chaos. The Cincinnati Bengals began this unprecedented, remote draft day by selecting the player who has spent months anointed as the No. 1 pick in waiting: Joe Burrow.

title: Europe's Banks Cannot Afford to Be Optimistic
summary: Modest loss provisions at Credit Suisse give an uncomfortable echo of the last crisis, when European banks were too slow to write down loans. European banks were too optimistic during the last crisis, setting investors up for years of pain. Judging by Credit Suisse 's first-quarter results, there is a risk that they will also prove too optimistic in the current one.

title: Fed Focuses on Lending Programs, But Monetary Policy Deliberations Loom
summary: Officials are likely to discuss their mid-range plans for asset purchases and policy guidance at next week's meeting. After several frenzied weeks creating a raft of emergency lending programs, Federal Reserve officials turn next week to planning and implementation rather than announcing new initiatives.

title: Coronavirus Lockdowns Slow Target's Roll
summary: Store sales petered out in late March as shoppers stayed home and moved purchases online, cutting into the retailer's profits.

title: Merkel Warns German States to Go Slow as Economy Reopens
summary: Despite a relatively mild coronavirus outbreak so far, Germany's chancellor says the country is still at the beginning of the pandemic. BERLIN-German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Thursday urged the country's 16 states not to be hasty in lifting economic restrictions following a slowdown in new coronavirus infections.

title: Two Villages, Two Eras, Two Plagues
summary: The author of a novel about the noble self-sacrifice of a 17th-century English town worries that today's pandemic isn't bringing us together. In the summer of 1990, before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait, I took a rare break from my job as a Middle East correspondent for The Wall Street Journal. Escaping the hot, dusty landscapes of my beat for a few days, I went for a restorative ramble amid the moist greenery of England's Peak District in Derbyshire.

title: New Yorkers Cremating Loved Ones Have Trouble Getting Funeral Aid
summary: City program designed to help families who can't afford burial doesn't pay for cremations. After Fernando Pena-Lopez died from the new coronavirus on April 6, his family immediately began looking for ways to properly bury him.

title: Credit Suisse Girds for Soured Loans as Profit Rises
summary: Swiss bank sets aside $584 million to cover potential loan losses from global corporations and Swiss borrowers. Credit Suisse Group AG joined U.S. banks in sharply raising provisions against potential losses from borrowers affected by the coronavirus shutdown, in the first report of first-quarter earnings by a major European bank.

title: U.S. Liquor Sales Come with a Pinch of Salt
summary: Spirits are outperforming beer in America as shoppers load up on expensive drinks. That might not last.. If you are using the lockdown to improve your home cocktail-making skills, you may not be the only one.

title: New York City Pension Funds Urge JPMorgan Shareholders to Oust Raymond
summary: The former Exxon Mobil chief is lead independent director at JPMorgan. New York City's pension system is joining the call for the ouster of Lee Raymond from the board of JPMorgan Chase & Co., saying the former Exxon Mobil Corp. chief "lacks the impartiality and climate competency" needed to fulfill his duties when it comes to climate-change risks.

title: The Debt Is Soaring; Debt Risks Are Not
summary: The usual fear is that high government debt leads to a crisis or excessive inflation. But there's little risk of the first, and nothing inevitable about the second.. The Trump administration has compared the pandemic to a war, so it seems fitting it is overseeing levels of borrowing last seen in World War II.

title: How Homeowners Can Give Food Scraps a Second Life
summary: Towns recognize the need to better educate residents about what food waste can and can't be recycled into compost, biogas, animal feed and other materials. With only a few months to go until Vermont's new ban on food scraps in landfills goes into effect on July 1, residents like Irene Nadler are in the dark about how it will work.

title: Chatbots Help Texas Officials Cope With Flood of Coronavirus Unemployment Claims
summary: Georgia, South Carolina also use AI-based bots to answer questions from jobless people in need of benefits. State unemployment offices are using chatbots to keep up with a flood of questions from people who have lost jobs amid the coronavirus pandemic and need to file a claim.

title: China's New Infrastructure Push Isn't All New
summary: Beijing wants to invest in 'new infrastructure' such as data centers and artificial intelligence, but for investors the impact is easily overhyped. As China prepares to accelerate public investments to kick-start its economy following the coronavirus shutdowns, "new infrastructure" has become a buzzword for brokers to sell investment ideas.

title: Shoppers Go Green to Clean Because There Is Nothing Else Left
summary: Clorox wipes and Lysol sprays are in short supply, so retailers try to fill shelves with eco-friendly alternatives. More Americans are buying cleaning products marketed as eco-friendly or all-natural, but not necessarily because they want to.

title: Coronavirus Lockdowns Lead to Surge in Digital Piracy
summary: Traffic to black-market television and film sites has jumped 30% or more in many countries. Films and hit shows such as "Contagion" and "Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness" have been huge draws for streaming services in recent weeks, and for illegal websites that host pirated copies.

title: 10 Financial Moves to Make If You Have Lost Your Job-or Fear You Will
summary: The wave of layoffs makes it imperative to have a financial plan in place, even if you're still working. Here's how to do it.. With tens of millions of Americans losing their jobs, the U.S. is approaching Depression-era levels of unemployment. Millions of households across the country are staring at their budgets trying to figure out how to save money, lower bills and cut back.

title: In South Africa's Most Famous Wine Region, Women Are Rewriting History
summary: By founding their own labels and operating the area's vineyards, a growing number of black women are succeeding in an industry that had long shut them out. To visit the rolling hills of the Cape Winelands, a traveler heads due east from Cape Town past the Cape Flats, an immense sprawl of settlements stretching south to the Atlantic coast. Viewed from the highway, the expanse of brightly colored housing is partly obscured by concrete fences. The Flats, as the area is known, comprises several townships built during the apartheid era, when race-based legislation such as the Group Areas Act forced nonwhite people out of urban centers.

title: Social Isolation's High Physical and Psychological Toll
summary: Studies of polar researchers, astronauts and others in isolation shed light on possible effects of social distancing, including increased forgetfulness, depression and heart attacks. When Newton, Mass., closed its schools in mid-March to help stop the spread of coronavirus, Nataly Kogan was thrilled. No more rushing to get breakfast. Her 15-year-old daughter, Mia, could sleep in.

title: The Big Winners of Sports Without Fans: The Refs
summary: Games behind closed doors will be bizarre. But economists believe referees will make better calls when they don't have people screaming at them.. The world's greatest athletes are just like us: When they go back to work, their offices will be unrecognizable. The next time there are games to watch, they will almost certainly be played in empty arenas, a reality that went from unrealistic to optimistic over the course of the most disruptive six weeks in sports history.

title: Drugmakers Prepare to Make Coronavirus Treatments
summary: Preparations would help make doses rapidly if testing pans out, but companies risk large outlays if the research doesn't succeed. Drugmakers are reconfiguring manufacturing plants and hiring hundreds of new workers to be ready to make coronavirus drugs and vaccines should they prove in testing to be effective in fighting off the virus.

title: Toilet Paper Giant Pivots From Scratchy Office Rolls to Battle Home Shortages
summary: Kimberly-Clark will shift to making more of the plush stuff as coronavirus lockdowns keep consumers on the hunt. The people who churn out oversize rolls of flimsy toilet paper for the office have a new assignment: make the good stuff.

title: Japan Won't Let IOC Off the Hook Over Olympic Costs
summary: IOC officials expect costs to rise by several hundred million dollars after Tokyo Olympics were delayed a year due to the coronavirus pandemic. TOKYO-Japan and the International Olympic Committee need further discussion over the financial burden of the postponement of the Tokyo Olympics, a senior Japanese official said, highlighting tension over who shoulders several hundred million dollars in expected costs from the delay.

title: Coal Suffers as Coronavirus Saps Power Demand
summary: Pandemic could hasten the end for some coal plants.

title: When Oil Prices Went Negative, Investors in China Took a Hit

Oil derivatives sold to Main Street investors, including some that could be bought with a few clicks on a bank app, have produced hundreds of millions of dollars of losses in South Korea and China.

title: Renault Lines Up State Aid as It Emerges From Lockdown
summary: Car maker is nearing agreement with banks and the French state to secure access to up to $4.3 billion to $5.4 billion in credit. PARIS- Renault SA is negotiating for billions of euros in state-backed loans as the French auto maker starts to reopen plants world-wide and slash costs to weather the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus.

title: Struggling to Focus? How White-Noise Apps Can Help.
summary: Unable to WFH amid the loud, discordant chorus of his neighbors, one quarantiner searches for the best sound-generating app to mask the racket. QUARANTINE, I SOON discovered, wasn't quiet. A particularly rude sort of cacophony undermined my work-from-home attempts after my company wisely banished me to my Brooklyn apartment in mid-March. The intrusive medley, care of my neighbors, included: "Je Suvivrai" ("I Will Survive" in French), played at a vicious volume 20-25 times a day, and children-clearly without deadlines-whose "indoor voices" could easily have projected throughout the Grand Canyon. Add to this: keening terriers, muffled anguish, and, roughly every hour, the rousing theme from "Game of Thrones" layered over "Je Suvivrai."

title: Muslims Worry Saudi Arabia Will Cancel This Year's Hajj
summary: The five-day religious event, which gathers millions of people in the Saudi Arabian city of Mecca and other sites, is due to begin in late July.

title: Poll: Majority of Young Voters Plan to Vote and Disapprove of Trump
summary: Engagement in the demographic has been on the uptick in recent elections. Younger voters are disenchanted but not disengaged.

title: Notre Dame Coach Muffet McGraw Retires but Will Continue Advocacy
summary: The Fighting Irish women's basketball coach won two national championships and gained wider fame arguing for more female leaders. Muffet McGraw, who coached the Notre Dame women's basketball team to two national titles and nine Final Fours in 33 years while fiercely advocating for female leaders, announced her retirement Wednesday.

title: If You Must Go Into Debt, Here's What to Consider
summary: Look at your options and map out a strategy, planning specialists say. Americans struggling to make ends meet in the coronavirus crisis may have to do something many would rather avoid-take on more debt.

title: Coronavirus Spurs Race in Latin America to Make Cheaper Ventilators
summary: Engineers, physicians and entrepreneurs are teaming up to make life-saving machines for fraction of market price. With the coronavirus pandemic bearing down on Latin America and ventilators in short supply, engineers, entrepreneurs and physicians are coming together with an audacious goal: building their own breathing machines from scratch in a matter of weeks.

title: Homelessness and Coronavirus: A Day in the Life of a Doctor Treating the Vulnerable
summary: Resume Subscription. CHICAGO-At 10 a.m. on a recent day, Dr. Thomas Huggett squared his shoulders and waded into a crowd of homeless people at a dimly lighted shelter on this city's West Side.

title: Getting a Mortgage-Payment Break Isn't the Boon Many Expected
summary: Some are told they will have to make lump-sum payments after forbearance ends, others get confusing information. WASHINGTON-A government effort to give Americans a break on their mortgage payments during the coronavirus pandemic hasn't provided the relief many homeowners were hoping for.

title: Call Center Operator Keeps Phone Lines Open During Pandemic
summary: Ben Davidowitz's company in the Philippines fields customer calls from employees' homes; 'we can't have roosters in the background'. Ben Davidowitz moved to the Philippines in 2010 to open call centers that allowed global companies to move their customer support services offshore. The coronavirus pandemic has forced the American entrepreneur to find a way for his workers to serve global customers from their crowded metro-Manila apartments.

title: Quibi's Head of Brand Marketing Exits After Launch
summary: Megan Imbres, who oversaw creative development for Quibi's high-profile ads, is leaving the company after a year. The marketing executive who helped develop Quibi's Oscars-night and Super Bowl ads is leaving the short-form streaming service shortly after its launch, the company said.

title: Harvard Won't Take Stimulus Funds After White House Pressure
summary: Trump complained about Harvard getting coronavirus aid under a higher education program; Stanford and Princeton also declined funding. WASHINGTON-At least three major universities said they wouldn't accept funds allocated to them under the coronavirus stimulus package after President Trump began pressuring Harvard University over the money.

title: Coronavirus Made America's Biggest Banks Even Bigger
summary: Some $1 trillion in deposits flooded in during the first quarter-with more than half going to JPMorgan, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Citigroup. Call it a reverse run on the bank.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: HHS Official Says He Was Ousted Over Coronavirus Drug Dispute
summary: Rick Bright says he was pushed out of key vaccine development agency because of disagreements over hydroxychloroquine, a drug promoted by Trump. WASHINGTON-A vaccine expert who was suddenly ousted from his post leading a federal biomedical division said Wednesday he was transferred because he insisted the government invest in "scientifically vetted solutions" and not unproven treatments to combat coronavirus.

title: VA Didn't Publicly Acknowledge Shortages, Top Officials Say
summary: The department has to compete with the private sector and other federal agencies for N-95 masks. WASHINGTON-The Department of Veterans Affairs was slow to publicly disclose the extent of mask shortages the department faced, as it dealt with an onslaught of coronavirus cases, top VA officials said this week.

title: Iran Says It Launched First Military Satellite
summary: Show of technology similar to missile program comes as Trump warns of retaliation against Iranian navy. The U.S. and Iran engaged in a new round of antagonism Wednesday, with President Trump threatening to destroy Iranian boats that harass the U.S. Navy, and Iran saying its Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps successfully launched its first military satellite into space.

title: First Virus Deaths in U.S. Came Earlier Than Authorities Thought
summary: Fatalities in California challenge the pandemic's timeline as countries continue efforts to help their economies. A pair of newly reported deaths in California have challenged the longstanding timeline of the coronavirus pandemic, raising new questions about when and how the virus first arrived in the U.S. and the costs of the nation's lack of preparation earlier in the winter.

title: McConnell Supports Giving States Bankruptcy Access
summary: Senate Majority Leader favors bankruptcy option over giving states more federal aid as they grapple with coronavirus. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said Wednesday that he supports the idea of allowing states to use bankruptcy protection to cut their debts instead of supporting them with more federal aid.

title: Venture Capitalist Gurley Isn't Joining Benchmark's Next Fund
summary: Lead investor won't be involved in new fund for first time since he joined firm in 1999. Bill Gurley-one of the most successful Silicon Valley investors of recent years after he placed an early and lucrative bet on Uber Technologies Inc.-won't be a part of a new fund that his venture-capital firm, Benchmark, is presently raising, according to people familiar with the matter-a sign that he may be stepping back from the future of the top-tier firm.

title: Pence Says Coronavirus Could Be Largely Past by Early June
summary: In Journal podcast interview, the vice president says U.S. is prepared if a second wave hits. Vice President Mike Pence said the White House hopes the coronavirus epidemic can be "largely in the past" by early June.
